message.content:
cs.RO, cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SY, cs.LG. 

The paper presents a simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) algorithm based on radio signals and the association of specular multipath components (MPCs) with geometric features. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Robotics (cs.RO) sub-category, which deals with the design and analysis of robot systems. The paper also develops a Bayesian model of the SLAM problem and represents it by a factor graph, which suggests that the paper may also belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) sub-category, which deals with the study of communication and information processing. The use of radio signals for localization and mapping suggests that the paper may also belong to the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-category, which deals with the design and analysis of computer networks. The paper also leverages the MPCs in the radio signal for improved accuracy and robustness of agent localization, which suggests that the paper may also belong to the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category, which deals with the analysis and design of complex systems. Finally, the paper uses belief propagation (BP) for efficient marginalization of the joint posterior distribution, which suggests that the paper may also belong to the Machine Learning (cs.LG) sub-category, which deals with the study of algorithms that can learn from and make predictions on data.
